p: We found the overall mean R 0 for CHIKV was 3.4 (95% CI 2.4–4.2). Our estimated R 0 of 4.1 (95% CI 1.5–6.6) for Ae. aegypti mosquitoes suggests CHIKV could spread rapidly and cause high disease incidence in urban areas, where this species thrives. Our estimated CHIKV R 0 for Ae. albopictus mosquitoes of 2.8 (95% CI 1.5–6.6) was lower than for Ae. aegypti mosquitoes. In rural areas, where Ae. albopictus mosquitoes are more prevalent, sylvatic cycles, maintenance of biodiversity including natural mosquito populations, and presence of hosts other than humans might reduce the effects of an outbreak. Early interventions targeting Aedes mosquitoes will be vital to controlling CHIKV outbreaks.
